list.item: Dinner at the home of the Carrs

p.del: school closes that morning - Shall mend - clear - pack - write letters - & do some visiting & take a few more kodak pictures - so expect to have a busy time. Aunt Lizzie & Mrs. Profitt will both be here.

Oh yes will you please send me my kodak pictures - have decided it costs too much to have two sets and think I had better keep them all in my new kodak book - The Washington D. C. Pi Phis know of my coming & no doubt I'll have to show them the pictures & talk about the school - & a book will be better than loose ones - Those I'm en-

closing you have not seen I believe & will you send them back with the others? I do not want the New Orleans pictures nor those of myself or those of the relations - just the burg Sevierville - environs - people etc. Do you suppose you can get them to me before I leave here?

div1.p:
Well to return to an account of my doings from Wednesday night on - After school that is about 4 p.m. for the play had to be gone over first - Emily - Lucrettie - Cora Ogle & I and oh yes Abby took the trail for Tom Camel's - cloudy afternoon but the mts were lovely & I see my first arbutus blossom - lovely too - Have you seen them? We had not been to the
Camel''s since our mountains visit last summer - when we took the tramp with them & wound up with moonshine -

They were both at home and entertaining a married daughter & child - Mrs. C. sat before the fire smoking a big "store pipe" (her corncob not visible anywhere) and holding the two year old granddaughter a pathetic little thing who wouldn't smile at all - her hair tied in tight braids with rags - shoes tied on her feet with the same as they were so torn they would have fallen off otherwise - her undergarment (diaper) consisting of pieces of an old kitchen apron - Friday little Blanche & Mattie Huff came over after school & for the night - I took them for a walk when I got home - We went up the river road & called on Mrs. Russell Ogle who is just recovering from the flu & is almost a skeleton is very thin anyway & tubercular too I imagine. Blanche & Mattie played empinole with Abby & me after supper - a most hilarious performance - Then Blanche & I went to bed - was much flattered to be elected as hostess for Miss B. for the night - She is a cute thing - is in Emily's room - Mattie is in Abbie's - They are both pretty as pictures - Yesterday it tried to snow in the a.m. but cleared off finally into a beautiful day - but I remained inside - did my Saturday work - wrote letters read & fussed around generally went to bed early. Emily did most of her packing - Blanche & Mattie were here & there & everywhere helping & enjoying the confusion generally - Little Lucinda Oakley came in - she had been to the store to get some new shoes & stopped "to warm" winding up by staying until after
lunch - Emily went home with her to tell them good bye -

Today the other girls went to Sunday School but as I shall be here two more Sundays decided to enjoy the lovely morning & walk over to the Carr's where we four girls had been invited for dinner. I don't enjoy riding over these rough roads & as the other girls wanted to ride we were all quite satisfied. So about 8:309:00 I set off with my kodak & strolled along the Roaring Fork Road meeting various ones bound for Sunday School although the last bell had rung some time before - They make no effort to arrive on time whatsoever - Saw a number of butterflies red bird - (do you know it?) bees - crows - squirrel - About two mile up the creek you take a footlog and go through a yard
close to the cabin & on up a ridge then down & finally up again and to a long narrow holler after a short steep climb - It's a three mile walk & their miles are not short! The girls arrived about half an hour later - Mr. & Mrs. Carr are very "good clever people but old fashioned" to quote Aunt Lizzie - They keep their children in school right along one boy and four girls - divided among the three rooms - They gossip terribly and have not the fine principles of the McCarters! Litha and Rose are planning to go to Carson-Newman College next year - a Baptist school in Jefferson City - small town in northeastern Tenn. - They have two brothers there now in school - We girls say that all the mischief making - (quarrels among the girls) are always goes back to
one of the Carrs - Well they were all very pleasant to us & did their best - We had the usual dinner in the kitchen - Then they got together their small flock of sheep & we took pictures later tramping over the rockiest field - nothing but rocks - over a ridge up & down for a good long mile to Roaring Fork. After our return we sat around the fire & started home about 3:30 - the girls drove & I walked with Ethel and Maud Clabo - the latter lives with her grandmother not far from them & came over during dinner. The two little girls stayed for supper & went to B.Y. - Emily & I didn't go - I did my school work & E. wrote a letter.

It's "now" more than bedtime & I must wind up this long epistle. Do consider the wild plan in the first part of letter very seriously won't you? I really would like to find something else to do besides teaching & shall make an effort strenuously to do so - If I do not succeed will then come back here no doubt - unless they find someone else as I told Miss Langmaid not to hesistate to do. Thank you for the offer of money - will need it if I come home but hope to earn enough to carry me through.
